Quick Facts

EXIT   X

HEALTH AND SAFETY AT WORK

Page

Table of Contents

 

 

In order to protect the health and safety of all people from work-related risks, the law imposes a number of duties on all parties. Although the following duties are only explicitly expressed in the WHS Act, their principles still apply in Victorian and Western Australian jurisdictions.

 

Click the numbers below for more information

 

1 Duties are not transferrable

 

If you are entrusted with a duty, you cannot delegate or assign that duty to someone else. If the duty is breached, you may be held responsible and penalised accordingly.

 

2 You cannot contract out of a duty

 

Any term of a contract or agreement that aims to exclude, limit or modify any part of the WHS Act or that aims to alter or transfer a duty to another person is void.

 

3 You can have more than one duty

 

Any person can have multiple duties, for example, if they hold more than one position as a duty holder under the WHS Act.

 

4 More than one person can have the same duty

 

Each duty holder must fulfil the duty by the standard that is required under the WHS Act. They must perform their duty to the extent that they have the capacity to influence or control the matter.
